All the domes will have plastic floors so no water is lost. Condensation forming on the ceilings will be drained into the water supply. I understand it like this: spaceX puts sports cars into space, and NASA does sciencey stuff in space.

SpaceX is not NASA. NASA has had more on its plate and definitely has a greater scope of operations. This is totally true. But comparing the innovations that SpaceX has made in the areas where SpaceX operates with NASA is totally fair game. There is NO reason why most of the innovation and technical advanced SpaceX has made couldn't have been done by NASA years... decades ago. Elon Musk talked about his experience sitting in board rooms at NASA explaining his vision for reducing the cost to space. He explained to them there should be no reason why the cost to space should be three orders of magnitude greater than the material cost and talked about his ideas for bringing that down. He described being literally laughed out of those meetings.

An indisputable case in point is SLS vs Falcon (9/heavy/BFR). In the same time that SpaceX has taken to do its incredible innovating, the ossified infrastructure at NASA brought us SLS. 1970's technology they've spent billions upon billions of dollars on, and worse, have publicly stated how they thought they were doing a great job with. "NASA SLS deputy project manager Jody Singer ... stated in September 2012 that $500 million per launch is a reasonable target cost for SLS" - merely getting the actual to orbit cost down to what the shuttle's subsidized sticker price used to be is their goal. They bet on SLS because it's a safe bet. Something they can throw money at and get an assured space launch vehicle. Assured because it's just the space shuttle without the orbiter.

For decades NASA has been the exact opposite of what they need to be. Risk and innovation averse for R&D, but crazily risk taking during operations. Every time there has been an accident or mishap investigation, the boards findings speak about how the culture at NASA is wrong for operations. Read up on the findings of the boards for Challenger, Mars Climate Orbiter, Mars Polar Lander, and Columbia. What they have to say about the culture and command infrastructure at NASA is telling, and is a common theme.

What that tells me, the risk taking during operations, and risk aversion for R&D, is that NASA, both historically and presently, has a culture of not rocking the boat. That is my definition of ossification. Don't rock the boat, sit back, and collect their stipend from congress. Unfortunately, those who point this out are said to be anti-exploration and anti-space.

Here in Canada we had a situation with our blood supply and the Red Cross, who at the time were the ones who did all our blood collection and distribution. They were determined to have a culture totally insuitable to handling something that important. They were stripped of that responsibility and all assets and infrastructure handed over to a newly created agency. The United States needs "A" NASA. "THE" NASA cannot, I believe, do the job any more. It has been allowed to continue on their current path just too long. There is no remedy that will fix them. I don't think much less than a complete shakeup will do the job. I would do the same thing to NASA as Canada did to the Red Cross. Disband them and give all their assets to a newly created agency. Get a completely new command team and hire people from the ground up.

Tim is too kind to see it this way, I think. And I get this. The first anywhere-near-real shuttle I saw was Enterprise in New York. That was almost a religious experience for me, finally getting to touch a real part of the actual shuttle program. I will never forget the horror of Challenger. I read that report, though, cover to cover, and by the time Columbia happened, it was with resigned expectancy that I accepted that news.

I really am sorry to say it, but NASA does not have, nor do I see a way forward for it to regain, my confidence.

Always love the videos and your enthusiasm for the future manned space flight programs. I remember vividly the day Challenger blew up, I was stationed aboard the USS Nevada SSBN 733 and we were tied to the pier for a missile load out, that day I was on watch below decks and we had both scopes up so that we could all have a look at the launch and believe me it was very clear and close looking through the scopes. Challenger had just lifted off, I stepped away from the con so the next man could take a look and then shortly after the announcement came over the Subs 1mc letting us all know Challenger had a catastrophic failure, I was 18 years old at the time and I remember it felt like I had the wind knocked out of me as was the expression i saw on everyone else's face around me. The Officer of the deck came across the Subs comms following the announcement and asked that the entire crew remove their covers, pause and reflect on the tragic loss we as a nation had just experienced, It was gut wrenching.
I remember watching the last moon landing and then the follow on NASA missions, Skylab which we almost lost due to damage on launch then one of the last Apollo Capsules docked with a Russian Soyuz Capsule and for a short time we had a sense of friendship, you see back then we still practiced duck and cover drills in school because the cold war was at it's peak it seemed and almost every public building in my small town in Ohio had a fallout shelter sign on it.
Now at age 51 I have a few things I want to say about "NASA". Many people do not realize NASA is not a public sector space program it at the end of the day belongs to the Department of Defense, civilian purposes come secondary. I often wondered if I would be alive for the Moon outposts NASA had promised us all as young kids or if I would ever see Werner Von Braun's Ring in the sky that I had read about in popular science magazines and then one day be able to go to Mars as a tourist as everyone was always talking about us colonizing Mars by the year 2000 with regular flights to and from, seems kind of silly now I guess.
True, NASA did accomplish many things and it is also true NASA inspired so many of us to dream and look to the stars but in the end NASA was (JMO) a waste of time. I still love space and SPACEX keeps me hooked as Elon Musk is not just a dreamer he follows through on what he sets out to do. I believe we would have accomplished many of the things I listed if we had just commercialized space in the 70's. NASA operating budget today is 50 million dollars a day, rounded up about 20 billion a year. The culture at NASA is much like the military in that you have allot of bureaucratic red tape and for many years innovation was stymied. Given the amount of money NASA has squandered and I say that because they really have not learned very much when you look at projects like ORION, SLS etc. ORION has much more technology and is almost twice the size of the Apollo Capsule but at the end of the day you still have a capsule and SLS is still a throw away package, not very impressive in my opinion when you consider how young SPACEX is and how very quickly they rose to the top because it was formed as a business and you do not start a business to loose money unlike the government which is in the business of spending and wasting money lolol.
I have followed the "MAR's" direct" folks and frankly think they more than most have the best, fastest and most economical approach with technology that has been built here and proven already, people keep saying how dangerous it would be and that the risks are too high and that may be so but there is no lack of courageous explorers highly trained knowing all the risks that are willing to go right now. In fact much of the technology needed we had already in place in 1973. To qualify on a Submarine you must know every system like the back of your hand, it is exhausting to get your dolphins or Submarine qualified, day and night you are studying, setting up interviews and physically touching every component on the Sub getting ready for your board interview, my board was 7hrs long and comprised of 5 crew members conducting the interview. What i do remember is a system we had on board the Sub called CAMS, it was the very same system used on the space shuttles, "CENTRAL AIR MONITORING SYSTEM" every compartment had a hockey puck sized disk that was constantly reporting the air quality in every space and where needed bringing scrubbers, filtration systems and oxygen bleeds online to keep the air perfect, it worked very well.
Have any of you ever heard of this project? I spoke with the gentleman heading this up and allot of their technology has been built some proven I have no idea where they are at today but check it out. https://gatewayspaceport.com/

Awesome video that puts the "argument" into perspective. We wouldn't be where we are today - and won't be going where we're going tomorrow - if not for governmental space organisations and commercial organisations.

This includes the Soviet Space Program and its post-Soviet descendants, NASA, ESA etc and all the various private contractors used over the years.

It's not "us vs them". No one organisation or government or company could do it alone.

One of the arguments I heard against the likes of SPACEX and Virgin Galactic was "no private company would do certain missions because they're not economically feasible - they won't make a profit out of them so they won't do them." That argument might be quite correct if you're looking at the private companies as islands unto themselves with nothing but their "bottom line" to drive them, but the way NASA pays private companies to provide the rockets to perform those sorts of "low-financial-return" missions and funds the experimentation out of its own budget just shows how short-sighted and fallacious that argument was.

I think you're right.  NASA is needed to explore and to do science.  However, it is the commercial space industry that are best suited to develop and build the infrastructure to help NASA conduct its mission.

Private companies will always outperform government agencies because profit offers a feedback loop and incentive to increase efficiency (reduce costs while providing the same or better product/services). Government agencies operate on endless stolen money that is always refreshed so there is no incentive to innovate or reduce waste/costs. They just move along at a snails pace because that fat paycheck will always be there, whether you earn it or not.

I just want to point out, Commercial Orbital Transportation Services (COTS) is a backronym from the long used Commercial Off The Shelf (COTS), which is an acronym that has been used for a very, very long time within the government vernacular.  FYI, the opposite of COTS is GOTS, or Government Off The Shelf.  The whole point being, that instead of developing something brand new, you use an already developed system and adapt it to serve your current purpose.  COTS being ready to use systems developed by industry with industry funds, and GOTS ready to use systems that were developed specifically for the government using government funds.

Just FYI about the comment near the beginning.  The Redstone missile that launched Freedom 7 (and Liberty Bell 7) was an IRBM, not an ICBM.  That means "Intermediate Range."  It couldn't reach the ~5,000 mile range to be called "Intercontinental."  The Atlas, used with the rest of the Mercury flights, and the Titan II, used with the Gemini program, were ICBM's.

For a very long time, access to LEO was the province of Governments. The cost to build your own rocket was so prohibitively high that you'd have never even considered it unless you were some kind of madman.
Enter a madman: Elon Musk. Bootstrapping a company with just $100M they got their fourth launch into space, then immediately abandoned that rocket and built a new one, which now has 52 successful launches under its' belt. By doing an end-run around traditional aerospace component suppliers, the total cost to develop and build both the F1 and F9 (with reuseability) was somewhere in the region of half a billion dollars. And they recover about 70% of the rocket.
SpaceX is the new poster-child of 'how to get things done and done cheaply'. If it wasn't for SpaceX we'd still be looking at SLS (and Orion) and thinking that sure, it's expensive, but that's what it costs to get back to the moon. But now that we do have this new benchmark some hard questions are being asked of NASA (when really we should be asking the 'Alabama Mafia' who are directing NASA to use expensive Shuttle-derived components). Even some in NASA now seem to be pushing the idea of launching the SLS four times (that's all they can launch before they run out of SSMEs), declaring victory, and cancelling the project.
With the advent of private access to space, (SpaceX, Rocketlab, Blue Origin eventually), NASA can get out of the business of launch hardware and double-down on what it does best, which is exploration and research.

Is there anything preventing NASA using the same funding model they use with Blue Origin and SpaceX on pure science endeavours?  Funding autonomous research groups in a range of projects and avoiding the bureaucracy that goes with a centralised agency such as NASA.
